author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Cooling the Economy Without Crushing It
description: Several signs of economic stress may keep the Fed from raising interest rates to a full percentage point.
content: This week, the Federal Reserve will decide on its next move for interest rates. The decision, expected to be announced on Wednesday, will almost certainly be to raise its benchmark rate. The U.S. economy is facing its worst bout of inflation in four decades, and higher interest rates are likely to slow the economy and ease price increases. But how much remains a question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Kushner Says He Was Treated for Thyroid Cancer While in White House
description: In a memoir to be published next month, former President Donald Trump’s son-in-law wrote that he wanted the diagnosis and treatment kept quiet.
content: Jared Kushner, former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, was diagnosed with thyroid cancer while he was serving in the West Wing, he wrote in an upcoming memoir set to be published next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: His Audio Speakers Are Coveted by Supreme, Mark Ronson and Prada
description: Devon Turnbull is the founder of Ojas, a high-end audio company. Previously, he was the streetwear pioneer behind Nom de Guerre.
content: Mark Ronson was renovating his West Village townhouse last summer when an urgent question arose: What type of audio speakers should he — a Grammy and Oscar-winning songwriter and record producer — procure for his living room?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: A Rebound for a Summer Pairing of ‘Hamlet’ and ‘Oresteia’ at the Armory
description: Two Robert Icke productions have endured illnesses and last-minute casting changes. Now they have finally settled into a repertory groove.
content: Perhaps more than any other production of this post-shutdown season, the Park Avenue Armory’s summer stagings of “Hamlet” and “Oresteia” — with their last-minute replacements and cast illnesses — have faced the most hurdles on their way to opening night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Energy Department will lend G.M. and LG $2.5 billion to build battery factories.
description: The loan will help the automaker and its supplier build electric vehicle battery factories in Ohio, Tennessee and Michigan.
content: The U.S. Energy Department said Monday that it would lend $2.5 billion to a battery maker owned by General Motors and LG Energy Solution to build battery factories, advancing the Biden administration’s plan to promote electric vehicles and reduce dependence on China for critical components.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Justice Department sues poultry processors over unlawful labor practices.
description: The department said three major processors participated in a decades-long scheme to suppress wages and stifle competition.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department filed a lawsuit on Monday against three large poultry processors along with a proposed deal meant to end what it described as a decades-long scheme to deceive workers and suppress wages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Russia looks to Africa.
content: Russia’s top diplomat, Sergey Lavrov, began a tour of four African countries yesterday. He is visiting Egypt, Ethiopia, Uganda and the Republic of Congo this week, where he seeks to blame the West for war-related grain shortages, which have sparked fears of famine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Berzon and Nick Corasaniti
title: 2020 Election Deniers Seek Out Powerful Allies: County Sheriffs
description: Conservative activists are working to recruit the law enforcement officers to their cause. Several sheriffs have already clashed with election officials.
content: LAS VEGAS — An influential network of conservative activists fixated on the idea that former President Donald J. Trump won the 2020 election is working to recruit county sheriffs to investigate elections based on the false notion that voter fraud is widespread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh and Hannah Seo
title: How to Live With Covid When You Are Tired of Living With Covid
description: The BA.5 surge is a reminder that we need to take precautions to avoid illness, slow the relentless cycle of new variants and minimize the disruption to our daily lives.
content: The United States is in the midst of another coronavirus surge, this time thanks to the Omicron subvariant BA.5. Scientists warn that the new subvariant appears to be the virus’s most transmissible version to date, and it is reinfecting people who have already dealt with previous variants once or twice, sometimes as recently as a few weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Frank
title: Kamala Harris Is Stuck
description: She remains a political partner to Joe Biden when America needs her to be a governing partner.
content: Just months after being sworn in as president in 1953, Dwight D. Eisenhower gave an unusual task to his vice president, Richard Nixon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norman Eisen and Amy Lee Copeland
title: This Georgia Prosecutor Has Donald Trump in Her Sights, and She’s Not Stopping
description: The Jan. 6 hearings have turbocharged Fani Willis’s investigation.
content: Now that the House Jan. 6 committee’s initial hearings have concluded, this is a useful time to evaluate their actual impact. For that, we should look not to Washington but well south of the Capitol, to Atlanta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ondine Cohane
title: Going Where the Wind Blows in Italy’s Salento
description: In this southernmost region of the country’s bootheel, the Ionian Sea is to the west, the Adriatic to the east, and the countryside is filled with stone walls and twisted olive trees, fields of long golden grass and wildflowers.
content: “Go to one of the inland cities today,” advises the burly fruit seller as he hands me a barattiere, a mixture of melon and cucumber that’s indigenous to Puglia, the region that forms the stiletto heel of Italy’s boot. “The sand will be blowing today on both the coasts, and you won’t be able to see the lovely colors of the sea.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Steve Cavendish
title: Woman Opens Fire at Dallas Love Field and Is Shot and Arrested
description: The shooting sent travelers scrambling for cover inside the airport, but no other injuries were reported, the authorities said.
content: A 37-year-old woman was taken into custody on Monday after she fired several rounds inside Dallas Love Field Airport in Texas and was shot and injured by a police officer, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Masala Cheese Toast, Courtesy of La Boîte
description: The New York spice boutique’s newsletter includes recipes to cook with their products.
content: La Boîte, the spice boutique in Hell’s Kitchen, delivers a free online newsletter with news about their products and creative recipes. A recent one for masala cheese toast by Kanchan Koya, a spice expert with a doctorate in molecular biology, evokes an after school snack she once enjoyed. It essentially is a grilled cheese sandwich: She mixes two cups of shredded Cheddar (vegan cheese is an option) with a minced shallot, a quarter cup of chopped cilantro, a bit of minced serrano chile, a half teaspoon of fine sea salt and a tablespoon of La Boîte’s masala blend. The mixture is piled on whole grain bread, covered with another slice and fried, pressed down in butter. The recipe serves four, but that depends on the dimensions of your bread. Like all of La Boîte’s recipes it calls for the company’s own spice mix, in this case Everyday Masala, but another masala would do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What to Know About California’s Head-Turning Gun Control Law
description: The state’s legislation is modeled after a Texas abortion law that went into effect last year.
content: By one measure, Californians are about 25 percent less likely to die in mass shootings compared with residents of other states. Our state’s low rate of gun deaths is at least in part because of our strict firearm laws, experts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: M.L.B. Players Choose Status Quo Over International Draft
description: The league and its players’ union could not agree on a plan to reform the acquisition of international amateurs. As a result, a compensation system for major league free agents will stay.
content: Major League Baseball and its players’ union couldn’t agree on the specifics of an international amateur draft ahead of Monday’s deadline, and thus the status quo will continue in the sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Hu
title: For Elaine Castillo, Reading Is Politics
description: The essays in “How to Read Now” pose earnest questions about interpretation, inheritance and human understanding.
content: “White supremacy makes for terrible readers,” Elaine Castillo writes in her essay collection, “How to Read Now.” The sentence, like the book’s title, is both a dig and a dare, which blooms into an urgent plea: “We need to change how we read.” For Castillo, born in California to Filipino immigrants, this “we” is “generally American”; her book is directed toward the marginalized communities that make up a large part of this country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: At Kono, the Chef Knows Chicken Inside and Out
description: The city’s greatest yakitori chef, Atsushi Kono, can find the flavor in thighs, skin, ovaries — even white meat.
content: One night last June, I found myself eating chicken skewers on the second-story terrace of a downtown hotel, wondering about the fire code.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: How to Talk About ‘Extreme Weather’ With Your Angry Uncle
description: What if everybody else is just as terrified to discuss climate change as I am?
content: NASHVILLE — Articles on how to talk about the warming planet with climate skeptics always thrust me into a state of mild anxiety. I live in Tennessee, where the governor professes not to understand what’s causing the country’s extreme weather. Right-wing pundits on the airwaves and right-wing trolls on social media dominate what passes here for public discourse on climate. Republicans funded by obscene oil profits keep doing the industry’s bidding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Smuggling Migrants at the Border Now a Billion-Dollar Business
description: With demand for smugglers on the rise, organized crime has moved in, with cruel and violent results.
content: CARRIZO SPRINGS, Texas — From the street, the little brown house was unremarkable yet pleasant. A bright yellow toy school bus and red truck hung on the hog-wire fence, and the home’s facade featured a large Texas lone star. But in the backyard was a gutted mobile home that a prosecutor later described as a “house of horrors.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Michael R. Long, N.Y. Conservative Party Stalwart, Dies at 82
description: His endorsement of George E. Pataki in 1994 helped elect the state’s only Republican governor in 50 years.
content: Michael R. Long, the devout ideologue who for three decades headed New York State’s Conservative Party — which in 1994 provided the winning margin to elect the state’s only Republican governor in the last 50 years — died on Sunday at his home in Breezy Point, Queens. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Rikers Island Guards Charged With Misconduct in Teen’s Suicide Attempt
description: The New York City correction officers and a captain stood by for nearly eight minutes as Nicholas Feliciano tried to hang himself in a jail cell.
content: For nearly eight minutes, more than a half dozen New York City Department of Correction officers stood by as an 18-year-old detainee named Nicholas Feliciano tried to hang himself in a Rikers Island jail cell, not intervening even when he flailed his arms and then went still.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: QAnon Candidates Aren’t Thriving, but Some of Their Ideas Are
description: While few with ties to the conspiracy theory are winning their primaries, themes pushed by QAnon followers have become Republican talking points.
content: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — Pamphlets, buttons and American flags cluttered booth after booth for political candidates at a conference center in Prescott, Ariz., this month. But the table for Ron Watkins, a Republican candidate for Congress who rose to fame for his ties to the QAnon conspiracy theory, sat empty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: As Prices Soar in Ukraine, War Adds Economic Havoc to the Human Toll
description: Fuel prices are up 90 percent from a year ago. Food costs have surged over 35 percent. Many people, with incomes no higher than before the war, are being squeezed.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — At his compact stall in Lviv’s main outdoor food market, Ihor Korpii arranged jars of blueberries that he and his wife had picked from a nearby forest into an attractive display. Fragrant dill and fresh peas harvested from their garden lay in neat piles on a table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In Robert Lowell’s ‘Memoirs,’ Mental Illness, Creative Friends and a Takedown of Dad
description: The poet’s memoirs are “densely yet nimbly written, and you sense Lowell’s judgment and discrimination in every paragraph,” our critic says.
content: In 1954, when he was in his late 30s, the poet Robert Lowell was committed to the Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic in New York City after a manic episode. As part of his therapy, he began to write personal prose about his family and childhood, to tap into the torrents that streamed below the glacier of his intellect. This writing was a trial run, of sorts, for the autobiographical poems in his breakthrough book, “Life Studies” (1959).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Feeling Better as He Seeks to Show He Is Still Working Despite Covid
description: The president’s symptoms “have now almost completely resolved,” the White House physician reported. Mr. Biden held two virtual meetings from isolation on Monday.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Monday that he was feeling better and sleeping through the night again as he recovered from Covid-19, and he expressed hope that he could return to work in person by the end of the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Sharon Otterman
title: As Monkeypox Spread in New York, 300,000 Vaccine Doses Sat in Denmark
description: The federal government adopted a wait-and-see response to the monkeypox outbreak, calling for more vaccines to be delivered only after cases were growing exponentially.
content: On the Thursday before Pride Weekend last month, hundreds of men dropped what they were doing and raced to a city-run health clinic in Manhattan. Finally, more than a month after monkeypox appeared in New York City, a vaccine was being made available to sexually active gay and bisexual men, among whom the virus was rapidly spreading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Has the Pandemic Changed Your Economic Situation?
description: Tell us about it.
content: The pandemic has drastically changed the global economy, affecting things such as the price and availability of goods and how people view their relationship to employers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Lizzo Earns Her Second No. 1 Song: ‘About Damn Time’
description: The singer and rapper’s disco-tinged hit follows her 2019 smash “Truth Hurts” to the top of the Hot 100. Her album debuts at No. 2.
content: If you have tuned in your local Top 40 radio station recently, or fired up TikTok, there’s a good chance you have come across Lizzo’s discofied hit “About Damn Time” (or at least, on your phone, found it in meme form).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Paul Sorvino, Master of the Mild-Mannered Mobster, Dies at 83
description: A would-be singing star, he found success in Hollywood playing a variety of roles, but they were often quiet, dangerous men, like Paulie Cicero in “Goodfellas.”
content: Paul Sorvino, the tough-guy actor — and operatic tenor and figurative sculptor — known for his roles as calm and often courteously quiet but dangerous men in films like “Goodfellas” and television shows like “Law & Order,” died on Monday. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis is expected to deliver an apology long demanded by Canada’s Indigenous communities.
description: OTTAWA — Pope Francis, on his first full day in Canada on Monday, is expected to ​apologize to ​Indigenous communities for the Roman Catholic Church’s role in ​the country’s notorious residential school system, ​​where thousands of Indigenous children died, and countless others were sexually and physically abused.
content: OTTAWA — Pope Francis, on his first full day in Canada on Monday, is expected to ​apologize to ​Indigenous communities for the Roman Catholic Church’s role in ​the country’s notorious residential school system, ​​where thousands of Indigenous children died, and countless others were sexually and physically abused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: As a Deadline Looms, the Dominican Republic Ponders a Draft
description: No country would be more affected by an international draft than the Dominican Republic. The players, coaches and trainers there remain divided as the issue comes to a head.
content: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic — Like so many children on this baseball-mad island, Fraidel Liriano wanted to sign with a Major League Baseball team and eventually play at the highest level. It could earn him and his family life-changing money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: Dimes Square Gets the Hotel It Deserves
description: Nine Orchard is a boutique destination for a neighborhood that isn’t sure it’s a neighborhood.
content: “I won’t tell you the molding story, but there’s a lot to the molding,” Andrew Rifkin said, standing inside a room in Nine Orchard, the new hotel on Canal Street between Orchard and Allen Streets. Mr. Rifkin is also proud of the custom ceramic toilet paper holders (“You need a place to put your iPhone while you’re in the toilet”), the round tables in rooms “wherever we can fit them — they’re hospitable”) and the apples and Saratoga Water that greet guests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Russia Cuts Gas Flow to Europe, Intensifying Fears It Is Weaponizing Fuel
description: On the eve of a European Union meeting to debate a gas conservation plan to make the bloc less vulnerable to a Russian squeeze, Moscow slashed the flow to Germany.
content: BERLIN — On the eve of a European Union emergency meeting on cutting natural gas consumption, Russia’s state-owned gas monopoly said Monday that it would slash gas deliveries to Germany, as President Vladimir V. Putin once again showed his unpredictability and his power to inflict pain on the bloc for backing Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Postseason Hope Weighs Heavily on Seattle Mariners Fans
description: The team’s 14-game win streak buoyed our columnist’s hope that the franchise could break a postseason curse. A visit from the Houston Astros brought on a familiar sinking feeling.
content: SEATTLE — The familiar sinking feeling returned quickly, in the first inning of the first game of the most anticipated Mariners homestand in a long, long while.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Vying to Lead Britain, Candidates for Prime Minister Emulate Another: Thatcher
description: Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss have tried to adopt the style and themes of Margaret Thatcher, the Iron Lady whose sweeping right-wing policies remain popular among Conservative voters.
content: LONDON — When Rishi Sunak kicked off his campaign for leader of Britain’s Conservative Party and prime minister on Saturday, his choice of venue — a tire shop in the market town of Grantham — felt almost inevitable. Grantham is the birthplace of Margaret Thatcher, an icon of the right who looms large in every Conservative leader contest, but never more so than in these economically straitened times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: From Flight Attendant to Funeral Planner: New Beginnings in the Covid Era
description: The pandemic upended careers in Hong Kong and around the world, forcing or inspiring people to make radical changes in their lives.
content: HONG KONG — Before she became a funeral planner, Connie Wong was a flight attendant for a Hong Kong airline. The sudden end of a career she had cherished for six years brought its own kind of grief, she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: The Movement to End Homework Is Wrong
description: Doing away with it would change the purpose of school itself.
content: Do students really need to do their homework?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: David Trimble, Peace Prize Winner in Ulster Strife, Dies at 77
description: A onetime Protestant firebrand, he surprised adversaries when he helped broker peace in Northern Ireland with the Good Friday pact of 1998.
content: LONDON — David Trimble, a onetime Protestant firebrand who surprised many by reaching across the bloodstained sectarian divide in his native Northern Ireland and went on to secure high office, political honors and a Nobel Peace Prize, died on Monday. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: Paul Sorvino: A Voluble Man Who Excelled as a Brick of a Mobster
description: The actor may be best known for “Goodfellas,” but he almost bailed on it because the character of the underboss Paulie Cicero was so difficult to pin down.
content: When Paul Sorvino was offered the role of Paulie Cicero, the Queens-based mob underboss in Martin Scorsese’s “Goodfellas” (1990), he very much did not want to accept it. In the first place, he was a proud Italian American. A connoisseur of Italian culture, particularly food and music, he was not inclined to play a Mafioso. In addition, Sorvino, who died Monday at 83, was a voluble guy, and he liked playing voluble guys. Paulie was largely a brick. Much is made in the early scenes of the movie about how most of the criminal’s directives were executed with a mere nod.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden Rule Would Strengthen Health Protections for Gay and Transgender People
description: The proposed rule would prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity by health care providers that receive federal funding.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration said Monday that it intends to enshrine anti-discrimination protections for gay and transgender people in the Affordable Care Act — a proposal that would officially reverse a policy adopted by the Department of Health and Human Services under former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Perlez
title: Where China Is Changing Its Diplomatic Ways (at Least a Little)
description: As relations with the U.S. and Europe plummet, Beijing is beginning a new wave of diplomacy in Africa, where it dominates trade with resource-rich nations.
content: Whirlwind visits to crisis-riven nations in Africa. A sleek training center for the continent’s up-and-coming politicians. The prospect of major debt forgiveness for a favorite African country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Sandy Hook Parents to Testify Against Alex Jones, and a Culture of Lies
description: The families of 10 victims have waited years to hold the Infowars conspiracist and the political environment that enabled him to account.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — The far-right conspiracy broadcaster Alex Jones spread lies for years about the Sandy Hook school shooting, saying it was staged by the government and that the families of the victims were complicit in the hoax. Juries will now decide in three separate trials how much Mr. Jones must pay for the suffering he caused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Pope Apologizes to Canada’s Indigenous People
description: Also, Myanmar executes four activists and China extends its reach in Africa.
content: Pope Francis offered a sweeping apology for the Catholic Church’s role in running boarding schools in Canada where Indigenous children were sexually and physically abused and where many died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub and Douglas Morino
title: 2 Killed in Los Angeles Park Shooting, Officials Say
description: Five other people were injured when shots rang out during a car club show, the Los Angeles Fire Department said. Authorities were considering whether “numerous” people fired shots.
content: Two people were killed and five were injured when one or more people opened fire during a car club show in a Los Angeles park on Sunday afternoon, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: As Women’s Soccer Surges, a Blind Spot Holds It Back
description: Most of the continent’s richest clubs do not employ a single full-time women’s scout. Other teams outsource recruitment to agents. The Euros have offered a rare chance to study up.
content: SHEFFIELD, England — Vicky Jepson has not found the driving all that bad. She has spent much of July on the road, racking up somewhere north of a thousand miles in only a couple weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: American Track Athletes Showed Up. Did American Fans?
description: Track and field officials were hoping that having the world championships on U.S. soil would help reignite American interest in the sport. But progress takes time.
content: Kara Winger arrived at the track and field world championships as one of the most decorated javelin throwers in American history. A nine-time national champion, she had persevered through injuries, including two knee surgeries, to compete at four Olympic Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Inside the Azovstal Siege
description: An account of Ukraine’s last stand at the steelworks plant in Mariupol.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Goodman Theater Names Susan V. Booth as Artistic Director
description: Booth, who currently leads the Alliance Theater in Atlanta, will succeed Robert Falls, who is retiring after 35 years leading the Chicago mainstay.
content: Susan V. Booth, the artistic director of the Alliance Theater in Atlanta, has been named the next artistic director of the Goodman Theater in Chicago, a dominant force in that city’s vibrant theater scene and one of the most influential regional nonprofits in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: 2 Killed and 2 Injured in Shootings in British Columbia
description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police responded after gunshots were reported in four locations in Langley, southeast of Vancouver. The gunman was fatally shot by the authorities.
content: Two people were killed and two others were injured, one of them critically, in shootings early Monday in four locations in Langley, British Columbia, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Will Reid, Rob Szypko, Sydney Harper, John Ketchum, Lisa Chow, Marc Georges, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: Death of a Crypto Company
description: The downfall of Celsius Network tells the story of an industry that became the thing it was trying to reject.
content: Born in response to the 2008 financial crisis, cryptocurrency was supposed to be a form of money that eliminated the traditional gatekeepers who had overseen the tanking of the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Top Pence Aides Testify to Grand Jury in Jan. 6 Investigation
description: Marc Short, who was chief of staff to Vice President Mike Pence, and Greg Jacob, a lawyer for Mr. Pence, were subpoenaed in the Justice Department’s expanding criminal inquiry.
content: Two top aides to former Vice President Mike Pence testified last week to a federal grand jury in Washington investigating the events surrounding the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, the highest-ranking officials of the Trump administration so far known to have cooperated with the Justice Department’s widening inquiry into the events leading up to the assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Daniel Berehulak
title: Eyeing a City Captured by Russia, Ukraine Prepares an Ambitious Counterattack
description: With soldiers, artillery and subversives, Ukraine has been laying the groundwork to retake Kherson, which Russia has held for months. But a counterattack would require huge resources, and could come at a heavy toll.
content: KHERSON REGION BORDER, Ukraine — The road to Russian-occupied Kherson in southern Ukraine passes through a no man’s land of charred wheat fields and cratered villages. The tails of rockets stick out of asphalt and the boom of incoming and outgoing artillery ricochets off tidy, abandoned homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Diana Kennedy’s Complicated Relationship With Mexican Cuisine
description: The brilliant and opinionated author, who died on Sunday, chronicled the recipes and culinary traditions of Mexico. Our critic considers her legacy.
content: Diana Kennedy sank into a dimpled leather chair at the Hotel Emma in San Antonio, leaned over her glass of Scotch and told me that the real enemy of every writer was mediocrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.5 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish-style home in Altadena, a Craftsman bungalow in San Francisco and a midcentury ranch house in Santa Barbara.
content: This house is 10 minutes from the center of Pasadena, but the views of nearby Hahamongna Watershed Park, a 1,300-acre protected green space, make it feel more remote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Politics of Litigation May Be Changing
description: For years it was mainly Democrats who used the courts to force social change.
content: Is suing a Democratic thing or a Republican thing? It used to be a Democratic thing, then it became a Republican thing, and now it’s a Democratic thing again. Or maybe it’s the other way around. Anyway, the politics of litigation have become confusing in an interesting way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein and Elias Williams
title: The Jackie Robinson Museum Is About a Lot More Than Baseball
description: Robinson accomplished a great deal on the field, but a museum celebrating his life — that will have a ribbon-cutting this week — puts as much focus on his civil rights work.
content: Jackie Robinson’s family home in Stamford, Conn., had a den featuring trophies, artifacts and a big scrapbook commemorating his many achievements. David Robinson, his son, fondly recalled in an interview how one wall held photos and plaques depicting his father’s success in sports. Another wall — with a collection twice as big — highlighted his father’s social activism, something of far greater significance to Jackie Robinson and his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Ohlin
title: Yes, I’m Pregnant. No, I Don’t Need Your Thoughts.
description: But chances are, you’ll tell me anyway.
content: I was very happy to be pregnant, and I considered it my business and nobody else’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Irma Vep’ and ‘Riverdale’
description: A mini-series from Olivier Assayas wraps up on HBO. And the long-running CW show based on the Archie comics ends its penultimate season.
content: With network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 25-31. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalley Huang
title: Gen Z Designers Made It Big on This App. Now They’re Graduating.
description: Depop, a social shopping app, was a springboard for many young designers during the pandemic. Some are now taking their success elsewhere.
content: When Shirley Tang started selling handmade clothing in 2020, she knew just where to do so online: Depop, an app at the forefront of social shopping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Meal Kits From James Beard Chefs-in-Training
description: Part of a Beard House chef residency includes creating a meal kit with dinner for two.
content: A new program at the James Beard Foundation, Beard House Fellows, uses the Beard House in the West Village for residencies for young chefs. There the chefs, mostly those who have completed training with the Careers Through Culinary Arts Program (C-CAP), work and learn. As part of the program they each create a meal kit with dinner for two, in collaboration with Great Performances for delivery nationwide. The cost of the kit helps support the residency, which is also funded by Capital One. From Wednesday through Aug. 9, the African fusion kit by Adijatu Jalloh, who graduated from New York City College of Technology and developing several business ventures, can be ordered for delivery on Aug. 24. Her kit contains ginger-scallion prawns, berbere-spiced cauliflower, wheatberry salad, peanut sauce, crispy shallots and, for dessert, cheesecake with strawberry compote; like the other kits, some simple preparations are required for the food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: U.K., Eurovision Runner-up to Ukraine, Will Host Song Contest in 2023
description: Organizers had ruled out Ukraine from hosting next year because of safety concerns from Russia’s invasion.
content: Eurovision organizers confirmed on Monday that Britain would host the popular song contest in 2023 instead of war-torn Ukraine, which as this year’s winner would have traditionally hosted next year’s event but was ruled out because of safety concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: The New Abortion Battleground
description: The political fight over abortion will increasingly be a battle over the mailing of pills into Republican-run states.
content: With Roe v. Wade overturned, many of the most intense battles over abortion access will involve the mailing of pills into Republican-run states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: There’s Hot, and Then There’s Hot as … Politics
description: In healthy democracies, the fringe bends toward the center. In our democracy, the center always seems to be lurching toward the fringe.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Damn, it’s hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Danny Hakim and Sean Keenan
title: Prosecutor Is Barred From Pursuing Criminal Case Against Trump Ally
description: A judge in Atlanta cited a conflict of interest on the part of Fani T. Willis. Her broader investigation into election meddling will continue.
content: ATLANTA — In an embarrassing blow to the prosecutor investigating election interference by former President Donald J. Trump, an Atlanta judge has disqualified District Attorney Fani T. Willis of Fulton County from developing a criminal case against one Trump ally, citing a conflict of interest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Sixth Teenager Charged in Central Park Jogger Case Is Exonerated
description: Steven Lopez had a robbery charge linked to the 1989 attack cleared from his record.
content: A forgotten co-defendant of the Central Park Five, who, like them, was charged with the rape of a jogger in a case that shook New York City and the nation, had a related conviction overturned Monday in downtown Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Seeks African Support
description: Also, the W.H.O. declares monkeypox a global emergency and a Chinese rocket will plummet to earth.
content: Russia’s top diplomat, Sergey Lavrov, set off on a tour of four African countries — Egypt, Ethiopia, Uganda and the Republic of Congo — seeking to place blame on the West for war-related grain shortages that have sparked fears of famine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Adams Blames Migrants for Shelter Woes. Critics Say That’s Too Simple.
description: There’s anecdotal evidence of an uptick in asylum seekers in New York City’s homeless shelter system, but advocates say it’s convenient to blame them.
content: Early last week, Mayor Eric Adams called for federal assistance to help with what he said was a flood of 2,800 asylum seekers who were making it difficult for New York City to fulfill its legal obligation to provide housing to those in need, known as the right to shelter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New York May Ban Pet Store Puppy Sales, a Practice Critics Call Abusive
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 25, 2022.
content: “The last bastion of nonpartisanship is puppies and kittens.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 25, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 25, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Covid and Monkeypox: Where New York City Stands
description: The BA.5 variant is going strong, but many New Yorkers no longer fear the coronavirus in the same way.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today, one topic: the state of the viruses — Covid-19 and monkeypox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: How the Path to Homeownership Runs Through Mexico
description: San Diego residents are moving to Tijuana to get more for their money. Some hope to save for down payments on houses that are way out of reach north of the border.
content: TIJUANA — Gustavo Galvez has dreams of owning a home in San Diego, Calif. His path toward homeownership, however, includes a detour: While he saves for a down payment, he plans to spend the next several years renting in Tijuana, Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Jakob Ingebrigtsen Wins the 5,000. ‘I Wanted to Prove that I’m a Better Runner.’
description: Ingebrigtsen found redemption against a decorated field that included Jacob Krop of Kenya, Oscar Chelimo of Uganda and Grant Fisher of the U.S.
content: In recent years, Jakob Ingebrigtsen has collected a small constellation of tattoos on his arms and legs. A crescent moon near his right biceps. A compass on his left forearm. A palm tree and the face of a dog above his right knee. A serpent on his left thigh. The tattoos are a source of fascination for track and field fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: South African Wine Without the Buzz
description: Lautus De-Alcoholised Wine, a new import for the United States, offers nonalcoholic sauvignon blanc and a red blend.
content: The choices when it comes to nonalcoholic wines, especially still wines, have been growing in recent years. Lautus De-Alcoholised Wine from South Africa is already five years old, but it’s a new import for the United States and a welcome addition. Like most of the more palatable products in the category it starts with real, well-made wine using grapes from several regions: sauvignon blanc for the white and for the red, a blend of shiraz, cabernet sauvignon and pinotage aged in oak. Then the alcohol is removed. The sauvignon blanc has refreshing minerality and good acidity with fairly tart fruit; the red delivers decent body, a touch of tannin and red fruit richness without being sweet. The company also makes a lovely moscato rosé, and white and rosé sparklers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: David Warner, Actor Who Played Villains and More, Dies at 80
description: He seemed destined for a major stage career but by the early 1970s was focused on film and TV. His credits included “TRON,” “Titanic” and hundreds more.
content: David Warner, who started his career on the British stage, including playing Hamlet with the Royal Shakespeare Company when he was just 24, then gravitated toward film and television, accumulating more than 200 credits, including “The Omen,” “Time After Time,” “TRON,” “Titanic” and “Wallander,” died on Sunday in Northwest London. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: An Amazing World Record Runs Into a Question: Was It Too Amazing?
description: After Tobi Amusan of Nigeria smashed a hurdles record at the world championships, the former gold medalist Michael Johnson raised doubts about the race’s unusually fast times.
content: Tobi Amusan of Nigeria set a world record in the women’s 100-meter hurdles on Sunday at the world track and field championships in Eugene, Ore. That by itself was not surprising: World records often fall at big events, after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: A U.S. intelligence report finds that Russia’s use of ‘filtration centers’ to detain and deport Ukrainians has intensified.
description: A newly declassified U.S. analysis found that Ukrainians detained in the centers may face deportation or imprisonment.
content: Russia is using more than a dozen so-called filtration centers in eastern Ukraine and western Russia to detain and deport thousands of Ukrainians, according to a newly declassified U.S. intelligence assessment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Tunisians Vote on Constitution That Could Threaten Their Democracy
description: The new charter would enshrine into law a vast expansion of executive power under President Kais Saied in the past year.
content: Tunisians voted Monday in a referendum on a new constitution that would greatly expand the powers of a president who, over the past year, has pushed aside the other branches of government to rule alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Russia Announces Deeper Cuts in Natural Gas Flows to Germany
description: Gazprom, Russia’s state energy giant, said it would halve the amount of gas it sends to Germany through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline, bringing it down to 20 percent of capacity.
content: BERLIN — Russia’s state-owned gas monopoly, Gazprom, said on Monday that it would further reduce the amount of natural gas it sends to Germany through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline, less than a week after it resumed limited flows after an annual maintenance shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada’s residential schools were a system of ‘cultural genocide,’ a commission found.
description: The investigation took testimony from more than 6,000 witnesses and reviewed thousands of documents over six years.
content: The investigation into Canada’s scandalous system of mandatory residential schools for Indigenous children was among the most comprehensive reviews in the country’s history, taking testimony from more than 6,000 witnesses and reviewing thousands of documents over six years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Is Beyoncé’s Definitive Album?
description: With the superstar’s seventh solo studio album, “Renaissance,” due Friday, our critics and reporters debate which work from her past reveals the most about her artistic vision.
content: Much is made of pop star “eras” these days, but the term is deployed as a tool of marketing, not meaning. Rare is the artist who can sustain multiple visions and repeatedly regenerate. But different cultural and social moments have demanded different Beyoncés, and she has consistently delivered. At times she has been a singles powerhouse, dominating the radio and pop charts. At others, she has announced herself as a seismic cultural force, playing on a field much bigger than music. On Friday she will release “Renaissance,” her seventh solo studio album. Below, eight New York Times critics and reporters choose what they believe to be her definitive album so far, the one that reveals the most truth about the scope and shape of her career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: The Monkeypox Emergency
description: The U.S. may have missed the opportunity to contain the largest monkeypox outbreak in the country.
content: The World Health Organization took the extraordinary step over the weekend of declaring monkeypox a “public health emergency of international concern,” a designation currently used to describe only two other diseases, Covid-19 and polio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: ‘The Better Bagel’ Goes All In on Nutrition
description: These alternatives provide more protein and fiber than the average bagel.
content: The rollout of the Better Bagel has been gradual, from an online debut about a year ago to a full complement of flavors now. Next month, its products will be available nationwide at Whole Foods. The “better” part of the name has merit; we’ll get to that. But except that it’s round with sort of a hole in the middle, bagel is not what I’d call this oversize, puffy and slightly sour breadstuff. It’s meant to replace your regular bagel with better nutrition; it contains more protein (26 grams) and fiber (35 grams) than the average bagel (9 to 12 grams protein; 2 grams fiber). The Los Angeles company founded by Aimee Yang, a Wharton School graduate, does not tout the fiber, though it should, focusing instead on the low net carbs (5 grams). Enjoyment requires toasting and liberal schmearing to amp up the flavor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Sunshades
description: Because it’s hot out there.
content: During a heat wave, we could all use some relief from the sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Oleksandr Chubko
title: As Ukraine Signs Up Soldiers, Questions Arise About How It Chooses
description: Recruiters approach young men on the street, but the standards are not always clear and there are reports of unwilling men being signed up while some eager to fight are turned away.
content: KHARKIV, Ukraine — At a subway station, a recruiting officer named Oleksandr, one of dozens deployed to different spots around Kharkiv, pulled young men out of the crowd recently, checking documents and determining whether they were eligible for military service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: Splitting T. Rex Into 3 Species Becomes a Dinosaur Royal Rumble
description: A team of researchers published a rebuttal to an argument advanced by another group earlier in the year. The disagreement over the king of dinosaurs is far from over.
content: The world’s most iconic dinosaur is undergoing an identity crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Brooklyn Clergyman Is Robbed While Delivering Sunday Sermon
description: A trio of armed individuals robbed Lamor M. Whitehead and his wife of  jewelry worth more than $1 million, police said.
content: A showy pastor who was in the middle of delivering his sermon and his wife were robbed at gunpoint of more than $1 million worth of jewelry at a Brooklyn church on Sunday, the police said. The heist was caught on a livestream video of the service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman, Jessica Testa and Sapna Maheshwari
title: Chaos and Creation: Inside the Making of Yeezy Gap
description: In 2020, two fashion brands announced an unusual alliance. Now that goods are finally hitting stores, is Yeezy Gap a corporate-creative cautionary tale, or a new model for fashion to come?
content: It was almost 90 degrees in Times Square on Thursday morning when a scene began to play out on Broadway that was so unexpected it could have been a mirage: 100 people were wrapped around the block outside the Gap, waiting for its doors to open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Romeo & Juliet’ Review: Older, Gentler Star-Crossed Lovers
description: With age-blind casting at the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival, two actors who have been married for 38 years play the teenage leads.
content: GARRISON, N.Y. — A romance and a love story are two different things. In art, we’re not great at differentiating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Joni Mitchell Performs Surprise Show at Newport Folk Festival
description: The 78-year-old artist performed a full set, her first in about two decades, at the renowned festival in Rhode Island on Sunday.
content: Joni Mitchell, the revered Canadian singer-songwriter and one of the defining musicians of the 1960s and ’70s, surprised an audience in Rhode Island on Sunday when she appeared at the Newport Folk Festival to perform her first full set in about two decades, guitar in hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Myanmar Executes Four Pro-Democracy Activists, Defying Foreign Leaders
description: They were the country’s first executions in more than 30 years. Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the ousted civilian leader who was detained during last year’s coup, remains in prison.
content: Myanmar’s military regime announced Monday that it had executed four pro-democracy activists, the first executions in the Southeast Asian nation in more than three decades and what was seen as the latest attempt to instill fear in a resistance movement that has continued to battle the junta since it seized power in a coup last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, David E. Sanger and Amy Qin
title: U.S. Officials Grow More Concerned About Potential Action by China on Taiwan
description: The Biden administration is watching for any moves by China to close off the Taiwan Strait, and they would prefer that Nancy Pelosi cancel her planned trip.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has grown increasingly anxious this summer about China’s statements and actions regarding Taiwan, with some officials fearing that Chinese leaders might try to move against the self-governing island over the next year and a half — perhaps by trying to cut off access to all or part of the Taiwan Strait, through which U.S. naval ships regularly pass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: ‘I’m Always Worrying’: The Emotional Toll of Financial Stress
description: Experts share tips on how to feel empowered and manage stress as prices continue to rise.
content: For Ellie Alvarado, a teacher and mother of three in Elgin, Ill., figuring out how to pay the bills has become a source of anxiety and tension, especially when she and her husband argue over how to cut back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: In a close race, Athing Mu comes away with an expected win.
description: Mu has become the first American woman to win the 800-meter world championship title, finishing with a time of 1:56.30
content: For the first time in her professional career, the American runner Athing Mu looked as if she could lose an 800-meter race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Rumrunning, Bootlegging and More Criminal History of ‘Liquor Island’
description: Long Island, with its extensive shoreline, became a focal point for figures like Dutch Schultz and Charles “Lucky” Luciano.
content: For Amy Kasuga Folk, the Southold Town Historian in Long Island, it pays to know the difference between the Prohibition terms rumrunning and bootlegging. As she explains in her book “Rumrunning in Suffolk County,” rumrunning is about boats bringing verboten liquor to shore from ships moored at sea, where the bootleggers pick it up and drive it to its destination. This teamwork, she writes, led to the rise of organized crime in the United States. Long Island, at one time known as Liquor Island with its extensive shoreline, became a focal point for figures like Dutch Schultz and Charles “Lucky” Luciano. The book covers the period of 1920 to 1933, year by year. A singular feature is a list of the hundreds of codes used by the smugglers from a notebook that a fisherman in Peconic Bay retrieved from the water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Prepares Another Rate Increase as Wall Street Wonders What’s Next
description: Central bankers around the world have been picking up the pace of rate increases. Now the big question looms: When will they slow down?
content: Federal Reserve officials are set to make a second abnormally large interest rate increase this week as they race to cool down an overheating economy. The question for many economists and investors is just how far the central bank will go in its quest to tame inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Scoops Go Flying at Catch‘n Ice Cream
description: At this NoHo dessert spot, balls of ice cream are mixed with toppings and tossed in the air by servers.
content: After rising through the ranks at Cold Stone Creamery franchises in Michigan and Missouri, Dylan Lemay, 25, considered a franchise of his own. But on the way he discovered social media, and began posting ice cream videos to YouTube and TikTok. Now, with millions of followers across platforms in his pocket and a few backers, he is opening an interactive ice cream shop on Friday in New York. There, balls of ice cream are mixed with toppings and tossed in the air by servers, thus the name: Catch‘n Ice Cream From Dylan Lemay. Prices start at about $7. Its NoHo location is in the landmark Bayard-Condict building, the only example of the architect Louis Sullivan’s work in New York City; Mr. Lemay said he selected New York for his first store and because of the tourist industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Dystopian Myths of Red America
description: The Big Lie about the election is embedded in an even bigger lie.
content: Desensitization is an amazing thing. At this point most political observers simply accept it as a fact of life that an overwhelming majority of Republicans accept the Big Lie that the 2020 election was stolen — a claim with nothing to support it, not even plausible anecdotes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Ex-congressman, banker and F.B.I. trainee are charged with insider trading.
description: The federal authorities filed criminal and civil charges against nine people in a series of unrelated cases that netted more than $7 million in gains from trading ahead of corporate mergers.
content: A former Indiana congressman, an F.B.I. trainee, a Wall Street banker and several others made for an unlikely grouping when the federal authorities on Monday announced the filing of criminal and civil insider trading charges against nine people in a set of unrelated cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: California’s Largest Wildfire Slows After Exploding Near Yosemite
description: The blaze spread rapidly over the weekend, bringing evacuation orders and threatening homes, in what so far has been a relatively modest fire season.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — After growing explosively to become California’s largest wildfire so far in 2022, a blaze in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada moderated on Sunday, with firefighters able to defend communities a dozen miles from Yosemite National Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: Money Alone Won’t Buy U.S. Tech Superiority
description: Semiconductor supremacy isn’t something we can buy. It’s something we must build.
content: Semiconductors, the tiny computer chips that run everything from smartphones to satellites to missile defense systems, are often called the “oil” of the 21st century. Maintaining U.S. economic and military might depend on a reliable supply. Semiconductor shortages during the pandemic brought some car assembly lines to a halt and left showrooms of home appliances barren, providing a glimpse of what would happen to the American economy if those chips ever ran out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Walmart lowers profit forecast as inflation hits customers’ wallets.
description: Citing the need to cut prices to move inventory, the company slashed its earnings outlook for the year, sending its stock price tumbling in after-hours trading.
content: Walmart lowered its profit outlook on Monday, saying inflation is pressuring its customers to make fewer purchases of general merchandise and to focus on necessities like groceries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla will spend more to increase production at two new factories.
description: Tesla said it expected capital expenditures to be $6 billion to $8 billion in 2022, up from an April forecast of $5 billion to $7 billion.
content: Tesla said on Monday that it was increasing spending by about $1 billion to ramp up its factories, develop new batteries and finance other projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: A Trump-Backed Veteran Ran Hard to the Right, Only to Be Outflanked
description: Joe Kent, a decorated retired Green Beret and House candidate in Washington State, is discovering just how far the modern far right will go.
content: Joe Kent, a square-jawed Trump devotee running for a House seat in Washington State, is in a bit of a pickle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Sharp Contrasts With Other Jan. 6 Inquiries Increase Pressure on Garland
description: The continued revelations from the House select committee and the rapid pace of the Georgia investigation have left the Justice Department on the defensive.
content: In the last week, local prosecutors in Atlanta barreled ahead with their criminal investigation into the effort by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies to overturn the 2020 election results in Georgia, targeting fake electors, issuing a subpoena to a member of Congress and winning a court battle forcing Rudolph W. Giuliani to testify to a grand jury.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Yakitori Master Moves Downtown
description: Atsushi Kono, the longtime chef at Torishin, has moved his omakase chicken-skewer tastings to Kono, a new restaurant in Manhattan’s Chinatown.
content: Atsushi Kono, the longtime chef at Torishin, has moved his omakase chicken-skewer tastings to Kono, a new restaurant in Manhattan’s Chinatown.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.5 Million in California
description: A Spanish-style home in Altadena, a Craftsman bungalow in San Francisco and a midcentury ranch house in Santa Barbara.
content: A Spanish-style home in Altadena, a Craftsman bungalow in San Francisco and a midcentury ranch house in Santa Barbara.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Says He’s on His Way to a ‘Full, Total Recovery’ from Covid
description: President Biden held virtual meetings as he recovered from Covid-19, telling reporters that he was “feeling better every day” and hoped to return to work in person by the end of the week.
content: President Biden held virtual meetings as he recovered from Covid-19, telling reporters that he was “feeling better every day” and hoped to return to work in person by the end of the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Indigenous Communities React to Pope Francis’s Apology
description: Indigenous leaders praised Pope Francis after he apologized for the Catholic Church’s role in abuse and forced assimilation of Indigenous people on their native land in Canada.
content: Indigenous leaders praised Pope Francis after he apologized for the Catholic Church’s role in abuse and forced assimilation of Indigenous people on their native land in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: The Hosts of ‘5-4’ Never Trusted the Supreme Court
description: With public confidence in the top judicial body at a record low, a leftist podcast is preaching to a growing choir.
content: For Rhiannon Hamam, it was a tossup between Bush v. Gore and Castle Rock v. Gonzales.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Opinion Columnists: So You Were Wrong. Or Were You?
description: Sampling the responses to the “I Was Wrong” collection of columns in Sunday Opinion. Also: Josh Hawley's run for his life.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Tackling crispy lamb, cumin tofu and more recipes.
content: Good morning. One of the many pleasures of working from the office after so much time away is rediscovering the restaurants I used to haunt at lunch time. My old friends! It’s largely been true, save for my return to the place where I liked to get dry-fried cumin lamb of fragrant excellence and remarkable, fiery complexity. It’s a limp, pallid, salty mess now. For this I put on dress shoes and took the subway?
source.name: The New York Times
